p: The proportion of blood-fed females that became infected (i.e., the infection rate) increased with the infectious dose ( Fig 1). The highest infectious dose (2.9 x 10 6 FFUs/mL) resulted in 74.5% and 75.6% infected females for Ae. malayensis and Ae. aegypti, respectively. Infectious dose was the only statistically significant ( p < 0.0001) predictor of infection rate ( Table 1), although there was a slight difference in the shape of the dose-response curve between the two species ( Fig 1). Although the OID 50 was similar between the two species, the OID 10 was lower for Ae. aegypti. The OID 50 was 5.97 log 10 FFUs/mL (95% CI = 5.81–6.14 log 10 FFUs/mL) for Ae. aegypti and 6.13 log 10 FFUs/mL (95% CI = 6.02–6.25 log 10 FFUs/mL) for Ae. malayensis. The OID 10 was 5.03 log 10 FFUs/mL (95% CI = 4.78–5.28 log 10 FFUs/mL) for Ae. aegypti and 5.59 log 10 FFUs/mL (95% CI = 5.41–5.78 log 10 FFUs/mL) for Ae. malayensis.
